item.title: UK Household Inflation Expectations Fell Before April CPI Spike
item.description: UK households had been expecting inflation to slow over the coming year, according to a Bank of England survey that was conducted before the sudden jump in consumer prices reported last month.
item.dc:creator: Philip Aldrick

media:content.media:description: Shoppers on the high street in Maidstone. Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

item.title: PSP Hunts for More Canada Deals as Assets Surge to $220 Billion
item.description: Canada’s Public Sector Pension Investment Board is looking to deploy more capital in its home country after years of global expansion that has pushed its investment portfolio to C$300 billion ($220 billion).
item.dc:creator: Mathieu Dion, Layan Odeh

media:content.media:description: Deborah Orida, president and chief executive officer of PSP Investments, during an event at The Canadian Club in Montreal, Quebec, Canada, on Monday, May 6, 2024. The Public Sector Pension Investment Board (PSP Investments) is one of Canada's largest pension investors.

item.title: No Clarity for Fed Until at Least September, Economists Say
item.description: It will take months yet before the Federal Reserve can get a clear idea of how Trump administration policy changes will shape the US economy, making officials unlikely to consider a change to interest rates before September, according to economists surveyed by Bloomberg News.
item.dc:creator: Maria Eloisa Capurro, Dana Morgan

item.title: Unrest Grips Bolivia as Dollar Crisis Sends Inflation Soaring
item.description: In the chilly hours before dawn in La Paz, Elizabeth Sánchez was queuing outside a Bolivian state-run grocery store, hoping to get her hands on two bottles of vegetable oil.
item.dc:creator: Sergio Mendoza

media:content.media:description: People wait in line to get some cooking oil on a street in La Paz, Bolivia, on June 4, 2025. A shortage of cooking oil in Bolivia has forced the rationing of up to 2 liters per person amid the country's ongoing economic crisis. The government attributes this to speculation and blames producers and sellers for hiding certain basic products, such as oil.

item.description: En las frías horas previas al amanecer en La Paz, Elizabeth Sánchez hacía fila frente a una tienda estatal con la esperanza de conseguir dos botellas de aceite vegetal.

item.title: South Africa Rail Firm Averts Strike as Unions Accept Deal
item.description: South Africa’s state-owned ports and freight-rail company reached a pay deal with its two recognized labor unions, averting a strike that threatened to disrupt mineral and agricultural exports.
item.dc:creator: Katlego Mtshali, Ntando Thukwana

media:content.media:description: A freight locomotive pulls wagons from the Transnet Pyramid South Depot in Gauteng, South Africa, on Friday, Nov. 17, 2023. Volumes of goods and commodities, including iron ore and coal shipped through the Transnet’s freight rail network for export, have dropped because of issues including vandalism, idle locomotives and cable theft. Photographer: Guillem Sartorio/Bloomberg

item.title: Korea’s Lee Urges Chaebols to Quell Distrust, Hears Trade Fears
item.description: South Korean President Lee Jae-myung called on the heads of the country’s largest conglomerates to help restore market trust while hearing out their concerns over the impact of Donald Trump’s tariffs on global trade.
item.dc:creator: Hyonhee Shin, Shinhye Kang

media:content.media:description: Lee Jae-myung

item.title: Israel’s Strikes on Iran Raise Shipping Fears Over Chokepoints
item.description: Shipping lines, brokers and analysts are warning of risks to key maritime thoroughfares in the Middle East after Israel’s strikes on Iran, a major escalation in a region vital to global oil supply and trade.
item.dc:creator: Weilun Soon

item.title: China’s Economy Withstood Trade Chaos But Momentum Likely Slowed
item.description: The Chinese economy rode out the tariff rollercoaster in May even as domestic consumption likely weakened again, after the government’s massive fiscal stimulus and frontloading by exporters offset shocks from abroad.
item.dc:creator: Josh Xiao

item.title: India, US Harden Trade Stance as July Tariff Deadline Nears
item.description: Trade officials from India and the US have hardened their stance on some key issues as they race to conclude an interim deal before higher US tariffs take effect in July, people familiar with the matter said.
item.dc:creator: Shruti Srivastava

media:content.media:description: A container ship docked at the Mundra Port of Adani Ports and Special Economic Zone Ltd. in Mundra, Gujarat, India, on Saturday, May 18, 2024. With a total market capitalization of $213 billion across 10 listed units alone, Adani Group controls vast swathes of the infrastructure that powers the nation’s growth and underpins the Asian expansion of companies from Apple Inc. to Amazon.com Inc.

item.title: Israeli Attack on Iran Raises Risk of Wider Conflict, Bloomberg Economics Says
item.description: Israel’s attack on the Iranian nuclear program and its ballistic missile sites threatens to spark wider fighting in the Middle East that risks drawing in the US, according to Bloomberg Economics.
item.dc:creator: Philip Glamann

media:content.media:description: TEHRAN, IRAN - JUNE 13: A building in Nobonyad Square is shown having suffered significant damage in Israeli airstrikes on June 13, 2025 in Tehran, Iran. (Photo by Majid Saeedi/Getty Images)

item.title: Caller ID Is Destroying Our Understanding of the Jobs Market
item.description: Britain’s statistics crisis is not unique — modern technology and changing habits are causing problems in many countries
item.dc:creator: Tom Rees, Molly Smith, Swati Pandey

item.title: BOJ Is Said to See Inflation Running Stronger Than Expected
item.description: Bank of Japan officials see prices rising a little stronger than they expected earlier in the year, a factor that may open the door to discussions over whether to raise interest rates if global trade tensions ease, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Toru Fujioka, Sumio Ito

media:content.media:description: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) headquarters in Tokyo, Japan, on Thursday, Dec. 19, 2024. The Bank of Japan kept its monetary policy settings steady as it bides its time for now, while a dissenter's proposed rate hike suggests momentum for another increase is building.

item.title: A $115 Billion Fund Manager Bets on Shortest Maturity India Debt
item.description: India’s economic growth is set to accelerate sharply, making the ultra short-end of the debt market the most attractive segment, according to one of the country’s top money managers.
item.dc:creator: Subhadip Sircar, Malavika Kaur Makol

item.title: Akazawa Sees a Deal With US Sparing Japan From Higher Car Levies
item.description: Japan’s top trade negotiator expects a trade deal with the US to spare Tokyo from higher auto tariffs, even if US President Donald Trump decides to increase them against other nations.
item.dc:creator: Yoshiaki Nohara

media:content.media:description: Ryosei Akazawa in Washington, DC, on June 6.

item.title: Peru Holds Key Rate as Policymakers Weigh Risks to Growth
item.description: Peru held interest rates unchanged as the central bank gauges whether US tariff policy will jeopardize its combination of the fastest growth and the lowest inflation among Latin America’s major economies.
item.dc:creator: Marcelo Rochabrun

item.title: Taxes and Tariffs Prompt UK Firms to Slow Hiring, Recruiters Say
item.description: British employers scaled back hiring further in May in the wake of the sharp tax increases imposed by the Labour government and US President Donald Trump’s trade war, according to a closely watched survey.
item.dc:creator: Irina Anghel

item.title: Xi Plays Long Game on US-China Trade as Trump Seeks Quick Wins
item.description: While Donald Trump hailed the outcome of trade talks in London, Xi Jinping walked away with an understated strategic gain: a negotiating process that buys China time and helps defuse the threat of more harmful tariffs and technology curbs.
item.dc:creator: Colum Murphy

media:content.media:description: TOPSHOT - Chinese President Xi Jinping applauds after a joint press conference with Brazil's President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva (not pictured) at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing on May 13, 2025. item.title: Wealthy Australians Brace for a New Tax on Retirement Savings
item.description: Australia is forging ahead with a new tax on its richest retirement savers amid concerns that the country’s A$4.1 trillion ($2.7 trillion) pensions system is becoming a high-wealth accumulation vehicle.
item.dc:creator: Richard Henderson, Amy Bainbridge

media:content.media:description: Pedestrians walk through Carlton Gardens in Melbourne, Australia, on Friday, April 5, 2024. Australians have become some of the world’s wealthiest retirement savers in large part because the law that created the super funds also established a steady source of funding.

item.title: China Forced to Keep Unprofitable Firms Alive to Save Jobs and Avoid Unrest
item.description: Saddled with the most loss-making industrial companies since 2001, Xi Jinping is trying to clean up his economy without triggering mass layoffs.

media:content.media:description: The Shaanxi Qinyang Changsheng Brewing Co. hasn’t turned a profit since 2020.

item.title: Argentina Inflation Hits Lowest Since Covid in Win for Milei
item.description: Argentina’s monthly inflation slowed to the lowest level since the height of the pandemic, scoring a major victory for President Javier Milei ahead of a crucial midterm vote.
item.dc:creator: Manuela Tobias

item.title: Key Senator Looks to Slow Ted Cruz Plan on Fed Interest to Banks
item.description: Senate Banking Committee Chairman Tim Scott said he opposes swift action on a proposal that would bar the Federal Reserve from paying interest on reserves to banks to help pay for Republicans’ massive tax and spending package.
item.dc:creator: Steven T. Dennis

media:content.media:description: Senator Tim Scott, a Republican from South Carolina and ranking member of the Senate Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs Committee, speaks during a hearing in Washington, DC, US, on Thursday, May 16, 2024. Martin Gruenberg, the embattled head of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. told lawmakers calling for his resignation that he was moving quickly to overhaul the agency's workplace culture after a probe detailed complaints of sexual harassment and discrimination at the agency.

item.title: IMF Sees Unwinding of Global Trade Surge Ahead of Trump Tariffs
item.description: The International Monetary Fund is seeing signs that the rise in trade and activity to front-run US President Donald Trump’s tariffs is beginning to unwind as the global economy still faces heightened uncertainty.
item.dc:creator: Ramsey Al-Rikabi

media:content.media:description: Loaded container ships at Felixstowe port in Felixstowe, UK, on Wednesday, April 9, 2025. The UK doesn’t plan to use a get-out clause to override her fiscal rules, even as the US tariff war roiled global markets, forcing down the pound and UK gilts.

item.title: Canadian Support for Counter-Tariffs Dips as Trump Trade War Persists
item.description: Canadians continue to support retaliating against US President Donald Trump’s wave of tariffs, but their fervor has waned as the trade war wears on.
item.dc:creator: Chaimae Chouiekh

media:content.media:description: Mark Carney, Canada's prime minister, right, and Dominic LeBlanc, Canada's minister responsible for Canada-US trade, during a news conference on Parliament Hill in Ottawa, Ontario, Canada, on Friday, June 6, 2025. Carney announced legislation on Friday to fast-track “nation-building” projects in Canada and remove internal barriers to trade in an effort to shore up the country’s economy from the US tariff barrage.

item.title: East Africa Plans Spending Boost to Offset Global Risk, Aid Cuts
item.description: East African finance chiefs increased planned spending to a record to sustain economic growth and mitigate the effects of geopolitical risks and cuts in foreign aid.
item.dc:creator: David Herbling

media:content.media:description: Pedestrians in the financial district in Nairobi, Kenya, on Thursday, June 5, 2025. Kenyan annual inflation remained below the 5% midpoint of the central bank’s target range for a 12th straight month strengthening the case for another interest-rate cut.

item.title: Bessent Sees Deficit Falling Over 10 Years After Tax-Cut Bill
item.description: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said that there are a number of different assessments of the deficit impact of Republicans’ signature tax-cut bill, and that his own expectation is it will shrink borrowing over a decade.
item.dc:creator: Cam Kettles

media:content.media:description: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent during a Senate Finance Committee hearing in Washington, DC, on June 12.

item.title: Trump Floats Higher Auto Tariff, Guts California Gas-Car Ban

Former President Donald Trump has reiterated an openness for Chinese automakers to build cars in the US as a way to boost the economy, signaling a potentially different approach from a Biden administration that has sought to keep out vehicles with links to the country.

item.title: US Mortgage Rates Tick Down, Sending 30-Year Average to 6.84%
item.description: Mortgage rates in the US fell for a second straight week.
